question: The test in which weight of lungs is compared with body wreight is/are: (PGI Dec 2008)
exp: Ans: B (Ploucquet's Test) In Ploucquet test, wt of lung is compared with body wt before respiration & after respiration in live birth. Sings of Live birth - Tests Used. Ploucquet's Test Q: The blood flow in the lung bed is so increased after breathing that their weight is almost doubled from 1/70 of the body weight before respiration to 1/35 after respiration. The increase in weight is not constant & is not a reliable indication of breathing. Foidere's Test or Static test Q: The lung are ligated across their hi la & separated. The average weight of both lungs before respiration are 30-40 gram & after respiration 60 to 66 gram. The increase in weight is due to increased flow of blood. Hydrostatic (or Raygafs) testQ: It is based on fact that on breathing, the volume of lung is increased, which more than compensates the weight of the additional blood, due to which their specific gravity is dimtnshed. The specific gravity of lung before respiration varies from 1040 to 1050 & after respiration about 940. This test is not necessary when-the foetus is monster, the foetus is macerated or mummified, the foetus is born before 180 days of gestation, the stomach contain milk & umblical cord has separated & a scar has formed. Wredin's testQ Change in Middle ear): With respiration air replaces the gelatinous substances, which found before birth, in few hours to five weeks. Breslau's second life test or stomach bowel test: If respiration takes place, stomach & intestine floats in water otherwise they sink. This is known as Breslau's second life test. Vagims Lfterinus: Child may breathe while it is in womb, after the rupture of the membrane. Vagitus vaginalis: Child may breathe while its head is in vagina. Therefore, proof of breathing is not the proof of live birth. Florence test Q: It is test for seminal fluid'1. The test is not the proof of seminal fluid, but only of presence of some vegetable or animal substances. A negative reaction proves that the stain is not seminal.

question: Involvement of erector pili muscle after death causes?
exp: ANSWER: (D). Cutis anserine. REF: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology By Gautam Biswas 2nd ed page 157. Cutis anserine = Goose skin= horripilation is granular appearance of the skin caused by contraction of erector pilorum muscles are found on the anterior surface of the body, particularly the extremities, seen in drowning. This is due to the rigor mortis of erector pilorum muscles of hair follicles in the skin and subcutaneous tissues

question: Test performed to compare weight of lung to body weight is?
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Ploucquet's Test Tests used in infanticide Ploucquet's test: o Weight of lung is measured in relation to body wieght. Before birth weight of lung is 1/70 of body weight and after respiration it becomes 1/35 of body weight due to increased blood flow in lung beds. Static test or Fodere's test: o The average weight of both lungs before respiration is 30-40 gm and after respiration is 60-70 cm. Hydrostatic test (Raygat's test, 1st life test): o The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000). o False positive hydrostatic test may occur (i. e. non-respired lung may float) in decomposition and in attempted artificial respiration. o False negative hydrostatic test (i. e. respired lung may sink down) may occur in atelectasis, pulmonary oedema, bronchopneumonia, and congenital syphylis. Breslau's second life test: o It assumes that a live born child would respire and therefore, would also swallow some air into the stomach and bowel. o Hence they float on water. This test is falsely positive in putrefaction (due to putrefied gases) or in cases of attempted artificial respiration. Werdin's test: o Before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue which is replaced by air after respiration.

question: Discoloration after death is first seen in?
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Dependent parts o It is seen on dependent parts of the body, therefore site depends upon position of body after death: 1) In supine: On posterior dependent portion of body. But not seen on back of shoulder blades, buttocks and back of calves due to contact flattening, i. e. toneless capillaries are compressed and occluded by weight and pressure of body. 2) In hanging: Dependent lower half of both lower limb and upper limb (i. e. lower half of leg with feet and lower half of forearm with hands), and external genitalia. 3) In drowning: Head and upper half of body as head being the heaviest part becomes the dependent part. It does not develop in running water due to constantly changing position of the body.
